header.title: The Book Of Ahriman
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Demonolatry, Chaos Magic

central_thesis: This book presents a syncretic system of demonolatry and magick, integrating Zoroastrian (Ahriman), Sumerian/Babylonian (Tiamat, Abzu, Nergal, Annunaki), and Lovecraftian mythos (Kutulu, Nyarlathotep) with modern occult practices. It redefines deities as sentient energy forces and outlines practical mechanics for rituals, self-transformation into a 'lich state', and manipulation of life/death essences, challenging conventional religious narratives through an adversarial and self-focused path.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces Ahriman (Angra Mainyu) as the Evil Spirit in Zoroastrianism, first-born of Zurvan, adversary of Spenta Mainyu, and creator of death. He is depicted as an all-destroying Satan who forged demons and prepared a legion for war against the host of heaven. His association with Lilith as his bride and the summoning of Kutulu (Leviathan) to destroy time are highlighted as central to his ultimate triumph.

Lilith is presented as the Semitic 'Layil' (Night) and storm demon, associated with screech owls and wild beasts. She is identified as Adam's first wife, who achieved enlightenment and became the Queen of Demons, mother of druj and daevas. Her connections to Hecate, Inanna, Medusa, vampirism, and her role in ancient creation myths and the spawning of demonic offspring are detailed.

structure_content.chapter_title: Kutulu and The Trinity of Existence
structure_content.summary: Kutulu is defined through Lovecraftian, Hebrew (LVYThN), Enochian (KRNZN), and Sumerian (man of Kutha) names, representing the destructive and creative persona of Angra Mainyu, harnessed from the Absu (Sea of Chaos). It is prophesied to destroy time and end Jehovah's Reign. The text then outlines a trinity of existence: Ab-Zu (primordial materials/will), KiaAma/Lilith (creator from Ab-Zu), and Kutulu (harnesser of Ab-Zu's will).

Cain is described as the physically born son of Samael (the Devil) and Lilith (through Eve), the first Satanist and murderer who gained vampiric nature by drinking Abel's blood. He wanders the Earth as a 'Dark Wanderer', spawning men and demons. The Nagas, half-human, half-serpent antigods, are introduced as enemies of Ahura Mazda, offering transformation to those who oppose the light.

A comprehensive listing of various psychoactive substances, including Adrenochrome Semicarbazone, Asarone, Atropine Sulfate, Belladonna, Betel Nut, Broom, Calea, Calamus, California Poppy, Catnip, Chicalote, Chodat, Colorines, Damiana, Dill, Donana, Epena, Fly Agaric, Harmine, Hawaiian Wood Rose, Heliotrope, Henbane, Hops, Hydrangea, Indian Snakeroot, Intoxicating Mint, Iochroma, Juniper, Kava Kava, Khat, Kola Nuts, Kuthmithi, Lion's Tail, Lobelia, Madagascar Periwinkle, Mandrake, Maraba, Mate, Mescal Beans, 5-MeO-DMT, Mormon Tea, Morning Glory, Nutmeg, Ololuique, Parsley, Passionflower, Pemoline, Pipilzintzintli, Psilocybe Mushrooms, Rescinnamine, Reserpine, San Pedro, Sassafras, Scopolamine Hydrobromide, Shansi, Shicuichi, So'ksi, Syrian Rue, Thornapple, L-Tryptophan, Wild Fennel, Wild Lettuce, Wormwood, and Yage. Each entry details material, usage, effects, and contraindications.

This section provides a glossary of common Sumerian words and phrases deemed useful for magickal purposes, including terms for 'Vampire', 'Destroyer', 'Evil God', 'Demon', 'Wicked Demon', 'God Of Death', as well as names for deities and places. It serves as a linguistic foundation for practitioners engaging with Sumerian-based magical systems.

Deities are conceptualized as sentient, intelligent forces of energy, not anthropomorphic figures. This section distinguishes between mythological narratives and Deism, advocating for a practical belief system focused on manipulating these energy forces. It outlines two basic ritual types: making requests to spirits/deities (invocation/evocation) and directly sending energy through intense emotional output (e.g., masturbation, self-mutilation).

Guidelines for constructing rituals emphasize defining a clear purpose, choosing appropriate methods (invocation/evocation), and maximizing emotional output. It cautions against preconstructed rituals and stresses personalization. The text controversially suggests that Enochian, a key magical language, was stolen and perverted into Hebrew, linking this to the suffering of the Jewish people and implying a corruption of ancient magical knowledge.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Evolution of Aeons and Enuma Elish Variation
structure_content.summary: A historical overview of aeons, beginning with the Aeon of Chaos (Apsu, Tiamat), transitioning to the Hebrew-dominated Aeon of YHWH, and anticipating a new aeon where the legions of Hell will destroy YHWH. A variation of the Enuma Elish myth is presented, depicting ABSU and TIAMAT as one, leading to the Elder Gods, their conflict, and Nergal's rebellion from Marduk to rule the underworld (Ki-Gal).

structure_content.chapter_title: Sumerian Deities, Black Flame, and Lucifer's Fall
structure_content.summary: Key Sumerian deities are defined, linking ABZU to 'sea of wisdom', IGIGI to 'entropy'/'surrounding gate', KUTULU to 'lord of the deep', ERESHKIGAL to 'queen of the underworld', and NERGAL to 'great lord'. The 'Black Flame' is introduced as a modern term for 'wisdom of the gods' and 'vitality', derived from Ab-Zu. Nergal is explicitly associated with Lucifer through the Babylonian tale of 'Erra And Ishum', correlating his attempted usurpation of Marduk's throne with Lucifer's fall from heaven.

Wicca's origins are discussed as a syncretic blend of Celtic, Mesopotamian, and Pagan elements, influenced by Crowley. The feminine aspect is linked to Nammu, and the masculine 'Horned-One' to Nanna or Kingu. The Annunaki are identified as 'children of heaven on earth' and 'feared eternal judges', explicitly linked to the Nephilim and Anakim. The Igigi are defined as 'pure spirit of wastelands', entropy, and the 'Tree of Death', distinct from the Annunaki but sharing a role as watchers.

structure_content.chapter_title: Liber Abzu: Book of the Sea of Wisdom
structure_content.summary: Liber Abzu details the concept of Ab-Zu as the 'Sea of Wisdom', the 'all' and 'nothing', the source of all energy and phenomena. It connects Ab-Zu to the Qabalah's Da'ath and the 'QBLHistic Black Flame', representing enlightenment and wisdom without shadow. The text then provides 'Ehu Abzu', a Sumerian Demonolatry Magickal System, for self-invocation and dedication to this primal force, emphasizing a deep, transformative connection.

This ritual is a yearly practice performed at specific times (e.g., 3 AM under the dark moon) and cardinal directions, dedicating oneself to the Abzu. It involves invocations to various deities (e.g., Ishnigarrab, Pazuzu, Bil Ur-Sag, Kutulu) at seasonal points like Beltane, Summer Solstice, Autumnal Equinox, Samhain, Winter Solstice, and Candlemas, aiming to strengthen works, purify, and make a lasting connection to primal forces.

A practical ritual designed for destruction against an enemy. It involves assembling specific tools, opening with purification, invoking 'spirits of destruction', and expressing intense negative emotions (hate, wrath) onto an item representing the victim. The rite is sealed by creating a sigil based on the destructive goal, charging it (via masturbation), and burying it with the defiled item to ensure the curse's manifestation.

A ritual for protection against harm, involving tools, an offering, and invoking chosen spirits for protection. The practitioner expresses fear and desires for safety, placing a sigil of protection on the sacrifice. The ritual is sealed by charging the sigil (via masturbation) while visualizing the spirit's comforting presence, and then securing it hidden.

This detailed treatise on necromancy covers its foundational skills and three main subdivisions: Fundamental, Vampiric, Eidolonic, and Transcarnate Necromancy. It emphasizes that necromancy is an active, experiential art requiring deep intuitive sensitivity to the ethereal realm and a rejection of conventional physical perception. The goal is to master the interaction with death essence and the spirits of the dead for various magical purposes.

This foundational aspect focuses on developing intuitive sensitivity to the 'death essence' and the condition of the soul. Practitioners learn to 'read' the ethereal body, diagnose 'maladies' at this level, and spontaneously reproduce the 'death essence' feeling. It involves quietening the mind and body into a trance state to interface with the netherworld, contrasting with conventional sensory reliance.

This subdivision focuses on 'life exchange' by 'feeding from the soul of another'. It involves 'sapping vitality' from a target by abrading their soul through a 'disjunction process', making it malleable for harvesting. The practitioner then overlays their own soul with the target's, absorbing life force to enhance their own condition. It is described as a parasitic relationship aimed at personal gain.

This branch deals with creating and interacting with 'eidolon' (apparitions or ghosts) from the netherworld. Methods include lucid dreaming to commune with the dead and overt summoning using various traditional or improvised techniques. The text highlights the challenges of communication with spirits, emphasizing intuitive reception over vocalization, and the need to discern the spirits' past experiences rather than expect future knowledge.

Focused on causing damage and casting hexes, this practice requires 'thanatoic sensitivity' to identify the ethereal condition of a target's body. Practitioners choose the most likely illness to induce based on existing weaknesses. Methods include 'soul-casting' (dislocating one's soul to directly interface with the target's ethereal form), communicating with spirits for aid, or harnessing 'death essence' directly to malign the target.

This is the ultimate goal, involving blurring the lines between life and death to achieve a 'lich state'—a heightened sensitivity to the netherworld while still connected to a physical body. Methods include synthetic regressions, dismantling senses, and deep meditation to shed corporeal elements and achieve 'bilateral existence'. The aim is 'gnosis' and perpetual awareness, becoming an 'embodiment of the living and dead worlds'.

This section delves into the connection between the Cthulhu Mythos, the Nephilim ('giants' or 'fallen angels' from the Apocrypha), and the Watchers. It argues that Lovecraft's Great Old Ones resonate with ancient accounts of cosmic, untamable beings that invaded Earth. The Watchers are depicted as angels who defied divine direction, taught forbidden arts to humanity, and bore the Nephilim with human women, leading to their banishment and the 'Flood'.

The Necronomicon is described as a foundational text within the Cthulhu Mythos, linking it to Sumerian and Babylonian mythology. The text argues that the original Necronomicon, titled 'Al-Kitab al-Mani', was a compilation of ancient source documents that preserved proto-human encounters with the Old Ones. It highlights the cosmic conflict between Tiamat/Cthulhu (Chaos) and Marduk/Elder Gods (Order), asserting that humanity carries 'the blood of the Other Side'.

key_concepts.definition: The Evil Spirit in Zoroastrianism, first-born of Zurvan, adversary of the Good Spirit, creator of death, and the all-destroying Satan; the Lord of Darkness who prepares legions for war against heaven.

The Bride of the Devil, Adam's first wife, Queen of Demons, mother of druj and daevas, associated with various ancient goddesses (Hecate, Inanna, Medusa), and a figure linked to vampirism and demonic spawning.

A multi-named entity (Lovecraftian, Hebrew LVYThN, Enochian KRNZN, Sumerian 'man of Kutha') representing the destructive and creative persona of Angra Mainyu, harnessed from the Absu (Sea of Chaos), prophesied to destroy time and end Jehovah's Reign.
The Sumerian 'sea of wisdom,' the primordial force, will, wisdom, and energy behind everything; the 'Living Continuum' and the 'all and not' from which all things originate.
A modern term for 'wisdom of the gods' and 'vitality,' connected to the Qabalah's Da'ath and Ab-Zu, symbolizing enlightenment and truth that casts no shadow.
A sentient and variably intelligent force of energy, not anthropomorphic gods. Deities are seen as forces of nature or cosmic energies that can be understood and manipulated through magical practice.

The operative side of magic, involving either invoking or evoking a spirit/deity for a request, or directly projecting energy through intense emotional output (e.g., masturbation, self-mutilation) to influence a desired outcome.
An ancient magical language believed to have been stolen and perverted by a Sumerian thief to create Hebrew, leading to a corrupted form of angelic communication.
Described as 'giants' or 'fallen beings,' children of the Watchers and human women, associated with ancient knowledge and magic, and identified as 'feared eternal judges' of the underworld.
A group associated with 'entropy,' 'those who see and observe,' and the 'surrounding gate,' linked to the Qliphoth and the Tree of Death, representing pure spirit of wastelands and anti-production.

The art and science of interacting with the realm of the dead, encompassing fundamental, vampiric, eidolonic, and transcarnate subdivisions, focused on manipulating death essence and spirits for personal or external effects.

A state of blurring the lines between life and death, where a living practitioner achieves heightened sensitivity to the netherworld, maintaining consciousness while appearing 'dead,' leading to 'gnosis' and bilateral existence in mundane and metaphysical realms.

A core necromantic skill, the intuitive ability to 'know' what death essence feels like, sense death nearby, and discern the condition of a target's ethereal body for purposes of hexing or soul manipulation.
The quintessence of the netherworld, a manipulable power used in thanatoic necromancy to cause damage, induce illness, or influence the ethereal body of a target.

practical_system.description: The practical system is a syncretic framework for operative magic, emphasizing emotional output as the primary energetic force. It combines invocations, evocations, sigil magic, and advanced necromantic techniques for a range of magical aims. The system encourages a deep, intuitive connection with primal forces (e.g., Ab-Zu, Kutulu) and offers methods for personal transformation, including achieving a 'lich state' and manipulating life/death essences.
tools: Candles, Incense, Oils, Music (for setting mood and enhancing energy)
Chalk, Salt, Sand, Flour (for casting circles)
Items representing victims/targets or sacrifices (e.g., effigies, personal belongings)

Psychoactive plants and chemicals (e.g., Adrenochrome, Asarone, Atropine, Belladonna, Psilocybe Mushrooms, Harmine, Kava Kava, Lobelia, Nutmeg, San Pedro) for altered states of consciousness in advanced practices.
rituals: Ehu Abzu: Self-Invocation and Dedication to the Abzu, performed under the dark moon at 3 AM to connect with primal chaos.
Kunuk Abzu: The Year-Long Rite, a series of seasonal invocations to various deities (Ishnigarrab, Pazuzu, Bil Ur-Sag, Kutulu) at cardinal directions for specific intentions.

Ehu Mitu: Destruction Ritual, involving the invocation of destructive spirits, intense negative emotional output, visualization, and the creation/charging (via masturbation) of a sigil to be buried with a defiled item representing the target.
Ia Salamu: Protection Ritual, invoking chosen protective spirits, offering sacrifice, intense emotional output, and the creation/charging (via masturbation) of a sigil for personal safety.
Circle Casting: A protective ritual involving drawing a double circle, inscribing seals/sigils, cleansing the area, and calling to cardinal directions for protection.
Setting Up And Executing A Gate: For making contact with chaos-oriented deities (e.g., Iak Sakkak), involving visualization, markings, and charging the 'gate' with personal energies.
Necromantic Trance State: A meditative practice to quiet the body and mind, allowing for intuitive interface with the death essence and spirits of the dead.
Vampiric Siphoning: A technique to 'feed from the soul of another' by abrading the target's soul and overlaying one's own to absorb vitality.
Eidolonic Creation: Methods for creating and communicating with apparitions or 'ghosts' from the netherworld, including lucid dreaming and overt summoning.
Thanatoic Hexing: Casting curses by leveraging 'thanatoic sensitivity' to the target's ethereal body, directing death essence, or commanding spirits to cause harm.

Lichform Transformation: A process of blurring the lines between life and death through synthetic regressions, dismantling senses, and deep meditative practices to achieve a heightened state of awareness and existence.

relevant_quotes.text: Our Dark Lord Ahriman Angra Mainyu or Ahriman is the Evil Spirit in Zoroastrianism. Angra Mainyu is the adversary of Spenta Mainyu, the Good Spirit. Angra Mainyu is Avestan, Ahriman is Middle Persian. Ahriman was the first born of the celestial God Zurvan, which is Infinite in time and space. In the Avesta he is called the twin-brother of the Holy Spirit, and contrasted with Spenta Mainyu.
Lilith, being the Bride of the Devil, is known by the Semitic “Layil” which a word is meaning Night, but also the name of the demon of the storm.

Kutulu: (Lovecraftian)"sleeping dark one", initiator of dreams LVYThN: (hebrew) lord of the raging sea KRNZN:"Choronozon" (enochian)lord of the abyss, lord of da'ath These are the names of the destructive and creative persona of Angra Mainyu, the force that has harnessed the Absu, the Sea of Chaos. It is this beast that will destroy time and end Jehovah's Reign.

Deities are real. Simple enough... Well, then, what is a deity? Is it a sentient and variably intelligent force of energy. The descriptions given by such grimoires and books as 'The Goetia', 'The Simonomicon', etc. are just the perceptions of the people who called these forces... which originally came from stories and such used to describe them.

The solution which vampiric necromancy presents is to feed from the soul of another. This is often considered sinister, unscrupulous, evil, or all of the above by many different types of magician, leading to a somewhat less than admirable reputation for vampiric necromancers.

The process of necromantic transcarnation has long been a fascination of the necromantic world. To turn into something which is still living yet resembles that which is dead (i.e.. "unlife") has been an obsession since the middle ages and continues into this day.

The Sumerians knew humankind was created not from the flesh of the Elder Gods but from the blood of Kingu, Tiamat's own. And they knew what that meant. We are of the blood of the Other Side, of undying dead-but dreaming Tiamat, and the Light at Center is Creation's chaotic wildfire.

critical_analysis.relevance: The book offers a radical, syncretic approach to occultism, blending Zoroastrian, Sumerian, Babylonian, Lovecraftian, Gnostic, Wiccan, and Chaos Magic traditions into a cohesive philosophical and practical system. Its core relevance lies in presenting deities as intelligent energy forces and providing detailed, operative instructions for personal empowerment, adversarial magic (destruction, protection), and advanced self-transformation (the 'lich state'). It challenges conventional religious and magical paradigms, positioning itself as a guide for those seeking a dark, self-directed spiritual path.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of experienced academic researchers and practitioners in Western Esotericism and Occultism, particularly those interested in demonolatry, Chaos Magic, dark spirituality, and left-hand path philosophies. It is explicitly not for novices or individuals seeking a 'one true god' dogma, requiring a deep understanding of occult concepts and a willingness to engage in challenging, often controversial, practices.
